Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story:
I stare at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen. My stepmom just texted, “Movie night in the living room! I made your favorite—pepperoni pizza. Come down soon!” I know she means well, trying to include me, making an effort to connect. As her step-child, I’m supposed to show appreciation, join in, and keep the lines of communication open. I haven’t checked in much this week, and I can feel the distance growing. 

But as I walk toward the kitchen, the smell of the pizza hits me. I glance at the pantry, where my kosher snacks are lined up, untouched. I promised myself I’d stick to kosher, even if it meant skipping out on family meals sometimes. My dad always says, “It’s important to keep in touch with your roots.” But my stepmom’s eyes light up when I join her, and I know she’s trying to make me feel at home. 

I stand in the hallway, torn between the warmth of her invitation and the quiet pull of my own beliefs, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
